    set-user-id ì‹¤í–‰íŒŒì¼ (Review)

    • íŠ¹ë³„í•œ ì‹¤í–‰ê¶Œí•œ set-user-id(set user ID upon execution)
      • set-user-id ì„¤ì •ëœ ì‹¤í–‰íŒŒì¼ì„ ì‹¤í–‰í•˜ë©´
      • ì´ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì˜ ìœ íš¨ ì‚¬ìš©ì IDëŠ” ê·¸ ì‹¤í–‰íŒŒì¼ì˜ ì†Œìœ ìë¡œ ë°”ë€œ.
        • í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì˜ ì‹¤ì œ ì‚¬ìš©ì ID (real user ID)ëŠ” ê·¸ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ì‹¤í–‰í•œ ì›ë˜ ì‚¬ìš©ìì˜ ì‚¬ìš©ì IDë¡œ ì„¤ì •ëœë‹¤.
        • ì˜ˆë¥¼ ë“¤ì–´ changì´ë¼ëŠ” ì‚¬ìš©ì IDë¡œ ë¡œê·¸ì¸í•˜ì—¬ ì–´ë–¤ í”„ë¡œê·¸ë¨ì„ ì‹¤í–‰ ì‹œí‚¤ë©´ ê·¸ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì˜ ì‹¤ì œ ì‚¬ìš©ì IDëŠ” changì´ ëœë‹¤.
          • effective IDëŠ” changì´ ì•„ë‹ˆë¼ ê·¸ íŒŒì¼ì˜ ì†Œìœ ì
      • ì´ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ëŠ” ì‹¤í–‰ë˜ëŠ” ë™ì•ˆ ê·¸ íŒŒì¼ì˜ ì†Œìœ ì ê¶Œí•œì„ ê°–ê²Œ ë¨.
    • ì˜ˆ : /usr/bin/passwd ëª…ë ¹ì–´ ì‹¤í–‰ íŒŒì¼

    Set-user-ID and set-group-ID (Review)

    • passwd programë¥¼ ì´ìš©í•˜ì—¬ passwordë¥¼ ë°”ê¿€ ê²½ìš°

    9.1 í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ ìƒì„±

    í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ ìƒì„±

    • fork() ì‹œìŠ¤í…œ í˜¸ì¶œ
      • ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ë˜‘ê°™ì´ ë³µì œí•˜ì—¬ ìƒˆë¡œìš´ ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ìƒì„±
      • ìê¸°ë³µì œ(è‡ªå·±è¤‡è£½)
    #include <sys/types.h>
#include <unistd.h>
pid_t fork(void);
    • ìƒˆë¡œìš´ ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ìƒì„±í•œë‹¤.
    • It is called once but returns twice.
    • ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì—ê²ŒëŠ” 0ì„ ë¦¬í„´í•˜ê³  ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì—ê²ŒëŠ” ìì‹ í”„ë¡œ ì„¸ìŠ¤ IDë¥¼ ë¦¬í„´í•œë‹¤


    • The child is a copy of parent.

      • Child gets a copy of the parentâ€˜s data, heap, and stack.

      • Parent and child often share the text segment.
        • ì‹¤í–‰ ì¤‘ì— ì½”ë“œëŠ” ìˆ˜ì •ë˜ì§€ ì•Šê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì—
      • data, heap, stackì€ ê³µìœ í•˜ì§€ ì•ŠëŠ”ë‹¤.
        • global ë³€ìˆ˜ëŠ” data ì˜ì—­ì´ê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì— ì´ë¥¼ ê³µìœ í•˜ì§€ ì•ŠëŠ” ê²ƒ

    • ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì˜ pidì—ëŠ” ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì˜ pidì¸ 15066ì´ ë“¤ì–´ê°€ê³  ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì˜ pidì—ëŠ” 0ì˜ ê°’ì´ ë“¤ì–´ê°€ê²Œ ëœë‹¤.

    • PCê°’ë„ ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ ê°–ë˜ ê°’ê³¼ ë™ì¼í•œ ê°’ì„ ê°–ê²Œ ëœë‹¤.


    í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ ì£¼ì†Œê³µê°„

    ë³€ìˆ˜ëŠ” ì„ ì–¸ê³¼ ë™ì‹œì— ì´ˆê¸°í™”ë¥¼ ë³´í†µ í•˜ëŠ”ë° ê·¸ë ‡ì§€ ì•Šì€ ë¶€ë¶„ë„ ìˆë‹¤. -> bss: generally 0ìœ¼ë¡œ ì´ˆê¸°í™”

    heap êµ¬ì—­ì€ ë™ì  ë³€ìˆ˜ê°€ ë“¤ì–´ê°€ëŠ” ê³³

    ì •ì  ë³€ìˆ˜ëŠ” ì»´íŒŒì¼ ë  ë•Œ ìƒì„±ëœë‹¤.


    í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ ìƒì„±

    • fork()ëŠ” í•œ ë²ˆ í˜¸ì¶œë˜ì§€ë§Œ ë‘ ë²ˆ ë¦¬í„´í•œë‹¤.
      • ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì—ê²ŒëŠ” 0ì„ ë¦¬í„´í•˜ê³ 
      • ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì—ê²ŒëŠ” ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ IDë¥¼ ë¦¬í„´í•œë‹¤.
      • ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì™€ ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ëŠ” ë³‘í–‰ì (concurrently)ìœ¼ë¡œ ê°ê° fork() ì´í›„ ë¬¸ì¥ì˜ ì‹¤í–‰ì„ ê³„ì†í•œë‹¤.
      • ì¦‰, thread controlì´ ë‘ ê°œ ì´ìƒì´ ëœë‹¤.


    fork1.c

    #include <stdio.h>
#include <unistd.h>
/* ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ìƒì„±í•œë‹¤. */
int main()
{
     int pid;
     printf("[%d] í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ ì‹œì‘ \n", getpid());
     pid = fork();
     printf("[%d] í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ : ë¦¬í„´ê°’ %d\n", getpid(), pid); //ë‘ ë²ˆ ì‹¤í–‰
}

    $ fork1

[15066] í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ : ë°˜í™˜ê°’ 0


    ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì™€ ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ êµ¬ë¶„

    • fork() í˜¸ì¶œ í›„ì— ë¦¬í„´ê°’ì´ ë‹¤ë¥´ë¯€ë¡œ ì´ ë¦¬í„´ê°’ì„ ì´ìš©í•˜ì—¬

    • ì„œë¡œ ë‹¤ë¥¸ ì¼ì„ í•˜ë„ë¡ í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆë‹¤.

if ( pid == 0 )
{ ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì˜ ì‹¤í–‰ ì½”ë“œ }

    fork2.c

    #include <stdlib.h>
#include <stdio.h>
/* ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ìƒì„±í•˜ê³  ì„œë¡œ ë‹¤ë¥¸ ë©”ì‹œì§€ë¥¼ í”„ë¦°íŠ¸ */
int main() 
{
     int pid; 
     pid = fork();
     if (pid ==0) { // ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤
         printf("[Child] : Hello, world pid=%d\n", getpid());
     }
     else { // ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤
         printf("[Parent] : Hello, world pid=%d\n", getpid());
     }
}

    $ fork2
[Parent] : Hello, world pid=15799
[Child] : Hello, world pid=15800

    parentì™€ chileì˜ ì‹¤í–‰ ìˆœì„œëŠ” ì¤‘ìš”í•˜ì§€ ì•ŠìŒ


    fork3.c: ë‘ ê°œì˜ ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ ìƒì„±

    #include <stdlib.h>
#include <stdio.h>
/* ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ ë‘ ê°œì˜ ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ìƒì„±í•œë‹¤. */
int main()
{ 
    int pid1, pid2;
    pid1 = fork();
    if (pid1 == 0) {
        printf("[Child 1] : Hello, world ! pid=%d\n", getpid());
        exit(0); //child process ì¢…ë£Œ
    }
    pid2 = fork();
    if (pid2 == 0) {
        printf("[Child 2] : Hello, world ! pid=%d\n", getpid());
        exit(0);
    }
}

    $ fork3
[Child1] : Hello, world! pid=15741
[Child2] : Hello, world! pid=15742


    fork()

    13í˜ì´ì§€

    • Example
    #include "apue.h"

int glob = 6; /* external variable in initialized data */
char buf[] = "a write to stdout\n";

int main(void)
{
    int var; /* automatic variable on the stack */ //uninitialized data
    pid_t pid;
    
    var = 88;
    if (write(STDOUT_FILENO, buf, sizeof(buf)-1) != sizeof(buf)-1)
        err_sys("write error");
    printf("before fork\n"); /* we don't flush stdout */
    
    if ((pid = fork()) < 0) {
        err_sys("fork error");
    } else if (pid == 0) { /* child */
        glob++; /* modify variables */
        var++;
    } else {
        sleep(2); /* parent */
    }
    
    printf("pid = %d, glob = %d, var = %d\n", getpid(), glob, var);
    exit(0);
}
    • ì‹¤í–‰
    $ ./a.out
a write to stdout
before fork
pid = 430, glob = 7, var = 89
pid = 429, glob = 6, var = 88
$ ./a.out > temp.out
$ cat temp.out
a write to stdout
before fork
pid = 432, glob = 7, var = 89
before fork
pid = 431, glob = 6, var = 88
$

    We never know if the child starts executing before the parent or vice versa. - It depends on the process scheduling algorithm.


    fork()

    • Information shared by child and parent.
      • real-uid(gid), effective-uid(gid)
      • controlling terminal
      • current working directory, root directory
      • signal handlers : ì´ë²¤íŠ¸ ë°œìƒ í†µì§€ ìˆ˜ë‹¨
      • environment
      • resource limits
    • differences between child and parent.
      • the return value from fork.
      • PID and PPID
      • childâ€˜s resource utilizations are set to 0.
      • pending signals - signal handlerëŠ” ê³µìœ ë˜ì§€ë§Œ signal ê·¸ ìì²´ëŠ” ê³µìœ  x
    • Two main reasons for fork to fail
      • if there are already too many processes in the system.
      • if the total number of processes for this real user ID exceeds the systemâ€˜s limit.
    • Two uses for fork (ì™œ forkë¥¼ í•˜ëŠ”ê°€?)
      • A process wants to duplicate itself.
        • Parent and child can each execute different sections of code at the same time.
        • Common for network servers.
      • A process wants to execute a different program.
        • Common for shells.
        • Child does exec() right after it returns from fork().


    ì‰˜ì˜ êµ¬ì¡° (revisit)

    While (true) {
    display prompt
    read command (command, params) // Get command or execution file
    if (fork() != 0) then { // Execute command or execution file
		wait(&status); // fork a child, wait for a child to finish
		exit()
	}
	else
		execve(command, parmas) // ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤
	} // ì…ë ¥ëœ ëª…ë ¹ì–´ë¥¼ ì‹¤í–‰

    $ ls
. .. /etc
/home /usr /dev
$ a.out
â€¦.
$

    while(true){
	display prompt
	read command(command, params)
	if (fork()!=0) then {
		wait(&status);
		exit()
	}
	else
		exec(command, params)
}


    SIGCHLD

    • When a process terminates, the kernel sends the signal SIGCHLD to the parent.
      • By default, this signal is ignored, and no action is taken by the parent.
    • Processes can elect to handle this signal, however, via the signal( ) or sigaction( ) system calls
    • The SIGCHLD signal may be generated and dispatched at any time, as a childâ€˜s termination is asynchronous with respect to its parent.
      • ë”°ë¼ì„œ ë°œìƒ ì‹œì  ì˜ˆì¸¡ ë¶ˆê°€.
    • But often, the parent wants to learn more about its childâ€˜s termination, or even explicitly wait for the eventâ€˜s occurrence.
    • This is possible with the wait system calls


    wait() and waitpid()

    • A process that calls wait() or waitpid()
      • Block, if all of its children are still running.
      • Return immediately if a child has terminated.
      • Return immediately with an error, if it doesnâ€™t have any child processes.(ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ child í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ìƒì„±í•˜ì§€ ì•Šì•˜ì„ ë•Œ)
        • forkë¥¼ í•˜ì§€ ì•Šê³  wait -> ì¦‰ì‹œ return


    í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ ê¸°ë‹¤ë¦¬ê¸°: wait()

    • ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ ì¤‘ì˜ í•˜ë‚˜ê°€ ëë‚  ë•Œê¹Œì§€ ê¸°ë‹¤ë¦°ë‹¤.
      • ëë‚œ ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì˜ ì¢…ë£Œ ì½”ë“œê°€ statusì— ì €ì¥ë˜ë©°
      • ëë‚œ ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì˜ ë²ˆí˜¸ë¥¼ ë¦¬í„´í•œë‹¤. ì˜¤ë¥˜ì‹œ -1 ë¦¬í„´
    #include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/wait.h>
pid_t wait(int *status);
pid_t waitpid(pid_t pid, int *statloc, int options);

    íŒŒë€ìƒ‰ ì„ ì€ blockí•˜ê³  ìˆë‹¤ëŠ” ëœ»


    wait()

    #include <sys/wait.h>

pid_t wait(int *statloc);
 		Both return: process ID if OK, 0 (see later), or -1 on error
    • wait()
      • If a child has already terminated and is a zombie, wait returns immediately with that childâ€™s status.
      • Otherwise, it blocks the caller until a child terminates.
      • If the caller blocks and has multiple children, wait returns when one terminates.
    • statloc argument
      • Pointer to integer
      • Store termination status (in case of normal termination) in the location pointed to by staloc.
        • And signal number (abnormal termination)
          • ì™œ ë¹„ì •ìƒ ì¢…ë£Œê°€ ë˜ì—ˆëŠ”ì§€ë¥¼ ë‚˜íƒ€ë‚´ëŠ” ì •ë³´
        • And if core file was created


    forkwait.c

    #include <unistd.h> â€¦
/* ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ìƒì„±í•˜ê³  ëë‚˜ê¸°ë¥¼ ê¸°ë‹¤ë¦°ë‹¤. */
int main()
{
    int pid, child, status;
    printf("[%d] ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ ì‹œì‘ \n", getpid( )); 
    pid = fork(); 
    if (pid == 0) { 
        printf("[%d] ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ ì‹œì‘ \n", getpid( )); 
        exit(1);
    }
    child = wait(&status); // ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ ëë‚˜ê¸°ë¥¼ ê¸°ë‹¤ë¦°ë‹¤.
    printf("[%d] ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ %d ì¢…ë£Œ \n", getpid(), child);
    printf("\tì¢…ë£Œ ì½”ë“œ %d\n", status>>8); //ì¢…ë£Œì½”ë“œê°’ì€ 4ë°”ì´íŠ¸ ì¤‘ 3ë²ˆì§¸ ë°”ì´íŠ¸ì„ -> 8 shift
}

    $ forkwait
[15943] ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ ì‹œì‘
[15944] ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ ì‹œì‘

    macros for interpreting the termination status

    termination statusë¥¼ í•´ì„í•˜ê¸° ìœ„í•œ ë§¤í¬ë¡œ í•¨ìˆ˜ - WIF

    • If not NULL, the status pointer contains additional information about the child (how the process terminated)
    • #include <sys/wait.h>
    • WIFEXITED (status);
      • returns true if the child process terminated normally
      • ì •ìƒì ìœ¼ë¡œ ì¢…ë£Œí•œ ê²½ìš°ì— ì°¸(TRUE) ê°’ì„ ë¦¬í„´
      • WEXITSATUS(status)
        • WIFEXITED()ê°€ Trueì´ë©´ exit í•¨ìˆ˜ì˜ ì¸ìì—ì„œ í•˜ìœ„ 8 ë¹„íŠ¸ ê°’ì„ ë¦¬í„´
    • WIFSIGNALED (status);
      • returns true if a signal that it did not catch caused the child processâ€˜ termination (abnormal)
      • WTERMSIG(status) : if WIFSIGNALED is True, fetch the signal number that caused the termination.
    • WIFSTOPPED (status);
      • Child í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ ì‹¤í–‰ì´ ì¼ì‹œ ì¤‘ë‹¨ëœ ê²½ìš°ì— ì°¸ ê°’ì„ ë¦¬í„´
      • WSTOPSIG(status)
        • if WIFSTOPPED is True, Child í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì˜ ì‹¤í–‰ì„ ì¼ì‹œ ì¤‘ë‹¨ì‹œí‚¨ ì‹œê·¸ë„ ë²ˆí˜¸ë¥¼ ë¦¬í„´
    • WIFCONTINUED (status);
      • return true if the process was continued, and is currently being traced via the ptrace( ) system call\
      • ì¤‘ìš” x


    • A process that calls wait or waitpid can
      • block (if all of its children are still running), or
        • wait() is called at any random point in time
      • return immediately with the termination status of a child, (SIGCHLD-asynchronous notification) or
        • ì˜ˆë¥¼ ë“¤ì–´ zombie process ê°™ì€ ê²½ìš°
      • return immediately with an error (if it doesnâ€˜t have any child processes) errno value:
      • ECHILD - The calling process does not have any children.


    wait(): macros for interpreting the termination status

    • Example
    #include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/wait.h>
void pr_exit(int status)
{
    if (WIFEXITED(status)) //case 1
        printf("normal termination, exit status = %d\n", WEXITSTATUS(status));
    else if (WIFSIGNALED(status)) // case 2
        printf("abnormal termination, signal number = %d\n", WTERMSIG(status));
    else if (WIFSTOPPED(status)) // case 3
        printf("child stopped, signal number = %d\n", WSTOPSIG(status));
}



    #include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/wait.h>
int main(void)
{
    pid_t pid;
    int status;
    
    if ((pid = fork()) < 0)
        printf("fork error");
    else if (pid == 0) /* child */
        exit(7);
    
    if (wait(&status) != pid) /* wait for child */
        printf("wait error");
    pr_exit(status); /* and print its status */ // case 1 ì‹¤í–‰
    
    if ( (pid = fork()) < 0)
        printf("fork error");
    else if (pid == 0) /* child */
        abort(); /* generates SIGABRT */ // ë¹„ì •ìƒ ì¢…ë£Œ
    
    if (wait(&status) != pid) /* wait for child */
        printf("wait error");
    pr_exit(status); /* and print its status */ //case 2 ì‹¤í–‰
    
    if ( (pid = fork()) < 0)
        printf("fork error");
    else if (pid == 0) /* child */
        status /= 0; /* divide by 0 generates SIGFPE */
    
    if (wait(&status) != pid) /* wait for child */
        printf("wait error");
    pr_exit(status); /* and print its status */ // case2 ì‹¤í–‰
}
    • ì‹¤í–‰
    $ ./a.out
normal termination, exit status = 7
abnormal termination, signal number = 6
abnormal termination, signal number = 8
$

    Each signal number is defined in <signal.h>
SIGABRT: 6
SIGFPE: 8


    wait.c

    #include <unistd.h>
#include <stdio.h>
#include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/wait.h>
int main (void){
    int status;
    pid_t pid;
    
    if (!fork ( )) //child
        return 1;
    pid = wait (&status); //parent
    
    if (pid == -1) //error
        perror ("wait");
    printf ("pid=%d\n", pid);
    
    if (WIFEXITED (status))
        printf ("Normal termination with exit status=%d\n", WEXITSTATUS (status));
    
    if (WIFSIGNALED (status))
        printf ("Killed by signal=%d%s\n", WTERMSIG (status), WCOREDUMP (status) ? "(dumped core)" : "");
    
	if (WIFSTOPPED (status))
		printf ("Stopped by signal=%d\n", WSTOPSIG (status));
    
	if (WIFCONTINUED (status))
		printf ("Continued\n");
    
	return 0;
}

    $ ./wait
pid=8529
Normal termination with exit status=1


    • If, instead of having the child return, we have it call abort( ), which sends itself the SIGABRT signal, we will instead see something resembling the following:
    $ ./wait
pid=8678
Killed by signal=6


    Waiting for a Specific Process

    #include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/wait.h>
pid_t waitpid (pid_t pid, int *status, int options);
	return: process ID if OK, 0 (see later), or -1 on error
    • Why waitpid() is required?
      • a process has multiple children, and does not wish to wait for all of them, but rather for a specific child process
      • wait() returns on termination of any of the children.
    • One solution would be to make multiple invocations of wait( ), each time noting the return value
      • wait() ì—¬ëŸ¬ë²ˆ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ë©´ì„œ ìê¸°ê°€ ìƒì„±í•œ ê²ƒì´ ë§ëŠ”ì§€ í™•ì¸ -> ë²ˆê±°ë¡œì›€
    • If you know the pid of the process you want to wait for, you can use the waitpid( ) system call
    • The waitpid( ) call is a more powerful version of wait( ). Its additional parameters allow for fine-tuning
      • Provides some controls with options argument


    pid_t waitpid(pid_t pid, int *statloc, int options);

    • The pid parameter specifies exactly which process or processes to wait for.
    • pid == -1
      • Wait for any child process. This is the same behavior as wait( ).
    • pid > 0
      • Wait for any child process whose pid is exactly the value provided. For example, passing 500 waits for the child process with pid 500
      • pidê°€ 500ì¸ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ ì¢…ë£Œë˜ì—ˆì„ ë•Œë§Œ ê¹¨ì›Œë‹¬ë¼
    • pid == 0
      • Wait for any child process that belongs to the same process group as the calling process.
      • ë‚˜í•˜ê³  ê°™ì€ process groupì¸ ê²½ìš°ì´ê¸°ë§Œ í•˜ë©´ ì–´ë–¤ child processë“ ì§€ ì¢…ë£Œë˜ë©´ ê¹¨ì›Œë‹¬ë¼
    • pid < -1
      • Wait for any child process whose process group ID is equal to the absolute value of this value.
        • For example, passing -500 waits for any process in process group 500.


    waitpid option parameter

    • The status parameter works identically to the sole parameter to wait( )
    • option - > ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì˜ ëŒ€ê¸° ë°©ë²•
    • WNOHANG
      • Do not block, but return immediately if no matching child process has already terminated (or stopped or continued)
        • if a child specified by pid is not terminated.
    • WUNTRACED
      • Do not block if a child specified by pid has stopped.
      • If set, WIFSTOPPED is set, even if the calling process is not tracing the child process.
      • ì‹¤í–‰ì„ ì¤‘ë‹¨í•œ ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì˜ ìƒíƒœê°’ì„ ë¦¬í„´
      • This flag allows for the implementation of more general job control, as in a shell.
    • WCONTINUED
      • If set, WIFCONTINUED is set even if the calling process is not tracing the child process.
      • ìˆ˜í–‰ì¤‘ì¸ ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì˜ ìƒíƒœê°’ ë¦¬í„´
      • As with WUNTRACED, this flag is useful for implementing a shell
    • wait (&status);
      • is identical to waitpid (-1, &status, 0);
      • 0 -> no option


    wait() and waitpid()

    • Example
    #include "apue.h"
#include <sys/wait.h>
int main(void)
{
    pid_t pid;
    if ((pid = fork()) < 0) {
        err_sys("fork error");
    } else if (pid == 0) { /* first child */
        if ((pid = fork()) < 0)
            err_sys("fork error");
        else if (pid > 0)
            exit(0); /* parent from second fork == first child */
        /* We're the second child; our parent becomes init. */
        sleep(2);
        printf("second child, parent pid = %d\n", getppid());
        exit(0);
    }
    if (waitpid(pid, NULL, 0) != pid) /* wait for first child */
        err_sys("waitpid error");
    /*
 * We're the parent (the original process); we continue executing,
 * knowing that we're not the parent of the second child.
 */
    exit(0);
}

    $ ./a.out
$ second child, parent pid = 1


    PID 1742ì¸ ìì‹í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ë¥¼ wait (waitpid) ìì‹ì´ ì¢…ë£Œ ì•ˆëœ ê²½ìš° ì¦‰ì‹œ ë¦¬í„´

    int status;
pid_t pid;
pid = waitpid (1742, &status, WNOHANG); // ë°”ë¡œ ë¦¬í„´ (ì¢…ë£Œë¥¼ í•˜ì§€ ì•Šë”ë¼ë„)
if (pid == -1)
    perror ("waitpid");
else {
    printf ("pid=%d\n", pid);
    if (WIFEXITED (status)) // status check macro function
        printf ("Normal termination with exit status=%d\n", WEXITSTATUS (status));
    if (WIFSIGNALED (status))
        printf ("Killed by signal=%d%s\n",WTERMSIG (status), WCOREDUMP (status) ? " (dumped core)" : "");
}


    Zombies

    • ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ wait()ì´ë‚˜ waitpid()ë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ê¸° ì´ì „ì— ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ ì´ë¯¸ ì¢…ë£Œê°€ ë¼ë²„ë¦° í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ë¥¼ zombie processë¼ê³  í•œë‹¤.
      • ì‚¬ì‹¤ìƒ ê°€ë¹„ì§€ ê°œë…ìœ¼ë¡œ ë´ë„ ëœë‹¤.
    • a process that has terminated, but that has not yet been waited upon by its parent is called a â€œzombieâ€
      • ì¢€ë¹„ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ëŠ” í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ í…Œì´ë¸”ì—ë§Œ ì¡´ì¬
    • Zombie processes continue to consume system resources
    • wait() returns immediately with that childâ€˜s status
    • These resources remain so that parent processes that want to check up on the status of their children can obtain information relating to the life and termination of those processes.
    • Once the parent does so, the kernel cleans up the process for good and the zombie ceases(stop) to exist.


    waitpid.c

    #include <sys/types.h>
â€¦
/* ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ìƒì„±í•˜ê³  ëë‚˜ê¸°ë¥¼ ê¸°ë‹¤ë¦°ë‹¤. */
int main()
{
    int pid1, pid2, child, status;

    printf("[%d] ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ ì‹œì‘ \n", getpid( ));
    pid1 = fork();
    if (pid1 == 0) {
        printf("[%d] ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤[1] ì‹œì‘ \n", getpid( ));
        sleep(1);
        printf("[%d] ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤[1] ì¢…ë£Œ \n", getpid( ));
        exit(1);
    }

    pid2 = fork(); // ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ ëŒê³  ìˆëŠ” ë„ì¤‘ì—ë„ ì´ë¥¼ ì‹¤í–‰
    if (pid2 == 0) {
        printf("[%d] ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ [2] ì‹œì‘ \n", getpid( ));
        sleep(2);
        printf("[%d] ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ [2] ì¢…ë£Œ \n", getpid( ));
        exit(2);
    }
    // ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ #1ì˜ ì¢…ë£Œë¥¼ ê¸°ë‹¤ë¦°ë‹¤.
    child = waitpid(pid1, &status, 0); //option 0: ìì‹í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ ì¢…ë£Œí• ë•Œê¹Œì§€ wait
    printf("[%d] ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ [1] %d ì¢…ë£Œ \n", getpid( ), child);
    printf("\tì¢…ë£Œ ì½”ë“œ %d\n", status>>8);
}

    $ waitpid

    fork() í›„ì— íŒŒì¼ ê³µìœ 

    • ìì‹ì€ ë¶€ëª¨ì˜ fd í…Œì´ë¸”ì„ ë³µì‚¬í•œë‹¤.
      • ë¶€ëª¨ì™€ ìì‹ì´ ê°™ì€ íŒŒì¼ ë””ìŠ¤í¬ë¦½í„°ë¥¼ ê³µìœ  (FD table, U area ë³µì‚¬)
      • ê°™ì€ íŒŒì¼ ì˜¤í”„ì…‹ì„ ê³µìœ 
      • ë¶€ëª¨ì™€ ìì‹ìœ¼ë¡œë¶€í„° ì¶œë ¥ì´ ì„œë¡œ ì„ì´ê²Œ ë¨
    • ìì‹ì—ê²Œ ìƒì†ë˜ì§€ ì•ŠëŠ” ì„±ì§ˆ
      • fork()ì˜ ë°˜í™˜ê°’
        • ë¦¬í„´ì„ ë‘ ë²ˆ í•¨
      • í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ ID
      • ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ ì„¤ì •í•œ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ ì ê¸ˆ, íŒŒì¼ ì ê¸ˆ
      • ì„¤ì •ëœ ì•ŒëŒê³¼ ì‹œê·¸ë„


    fork()

    ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ ìƒì„±ë˜ë©´ ë™ì¼í•œ ë‚´ìš©ì˜ file descriptorë¥¼ ê·¸ëŒ€ë¡œ ë³µì‚¬í•˜ê³  open file table ë’·ë‹¨ì€ ëª¨ë‘ ê³µìœ í•˜ê²Œ ëœë‹¤.(ê°™ì€ ê³³ì„ ê°€ë¦¬í‚´)

    • per process table

    ê°™ì€ open file entryë¥¼ ê³µìœ í•˜ê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì— íŒŒì¼ ì˜¤í”„ì…‹ì´ ê³µìœ ë˜ì–´ ë‘˜ì´ ê°™ì´ íŒŒì¼ì„ ì‘ì„±í•˜ë©´ ë¶€ëª¨ì™€ ìì‹ìœ¼ë¡œë¶€í„° ì¶œë ¥ì´ ì„œë¡œ ì„ì¼ ìˆ˜ ìˆìŒ


    Copy-on-write

    fork() ì˜ íš¨ìœ¨ì„±ì„ ë†’ì´ê¸° ìœ„í•œ ë°©ë²•

    • Copy-on-write is a lazy optimization strategy designed to mitigate the overhead of duplicating resources.
      • ìì‹ì˜ duplicationì„ ê°€ëŠ¥í•œí•œ ì§€ì—°
    • The premise is simple:
      • if multiple consumers request read access to their own copies of a resource, duplicate copies of the resource need not be made. Instead, each consumer can be handed a pointer to the same resource. (ì²˜ìŒë¶€í„° forkí•˜ë©´ ë°”ë¡œ copyí•˜ì§€ ì•Šë„ë¡ -> ê°™ì€ resourceë¡œ í¬ì¸íŠ¸ë¡œ hand)
    • So long as no consumer attempts to modify its â€œcopyâ€ of the resource, the illusion of exclusive access to the resource remains, and the overhead of a copy is avoided.
      • ìê¸° ë§Œì˜ resourceë¥¼ ê°€ì§„ë‹¤ê³  ì°©ê°
    • If a consumer does attempt to modify its copy of the resource, at that point, the resource is transparently duplicated, and the copy is given to the modifying consumer
    • modifyê°€ ì¼ì–´ë‚˜ì§€ ì•Šì€ ê²½ìš°ì—ëŠ” í•œ ê°œì˜ copyë§Œ ê°€ì§€ê³  ê³µìœ í•˜ë„ë¡ í•˜ë‹¤ê°€ ë§Œì•½ ë‘ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ ì¤‘ì—ì„œ í•œ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ modify í•˜ê²Œ ë˜ë©´ ê·¸ì œì„œì•¼ ë¹„ë¡œì†Œ lazyí•˜ê²Œ ë’¤ëŠ¦ê²Œ copyë¥¼ ë§Œë“¤ì–´ì¤€ë‹¤.


    fork()

    Copy on write

    • After parent process write a page C.

    readë§Œ í•˜ë©´ í¬ì¸í„°ë¥¼ ê³µìœ 

    cë§Œ modifyë¥¼ í•˜ê³ ì í•˜ë©´ ë³„ë„ì˜ copyë³¸ì„ ë§Œë“¤ì–´ ê°ì ë‹¤ë¥¸ ê²ƒì„ ê°€ë¦¬í‚¤ê²Œ í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì´ë‹¤.


    Vfork()

    • Creates a new process only to exec a new program
      • ì™„ì „íˆ ìƒˆë¡œìš´ programì„ ì‹¤í–‰ì‹œí‚¤ê¸° ìœ„í•œ ëª©ì ìœ¼ë¡œë§Œ ì‚¬ìš©
      • No copy of parentâ€™s address space for child (not needed!)
      • Before exec, child runs in â€œaddress space of parentâ€
        • ì£¼ì†Œ ê³µê°„ì„ ë‹¬ë¦¬í•˜ì§€ ì•Šê³  parentì˜ ì£¼ì†Œ ê³µê°„ì—ì„œ ì‹¤í–‰
      • Efficient in paged virtual memory
    • Child runs first
      • Parent waits until child exec or exit (block)
        • Then the parent resume
      • The deadlock(blockëœ ìƒíƒœ) possibility if the child wait for something from the parent
        • ë¶€ëª¨ì˜ ìì›ì„ í•„ìš”ë¡œí•˜ëŠ” ê²½ìš° -> deadlock ë°œìƒ ê°€ëŠ¥ -> êµ‰ì¥íˆ ë³µì¡í•œ ë™ê¸°í™” ê¸°ìˆ ë¡œ í•´ê²°


    vfork()

    #include <unistd.h>

pid_t vfork(void);
 	//Returns: 0 in child, process ID of child in parent, -1 on error
    • same calling sequence and same return values as fork().
    • intended to create a new process when the purpose of the new process is to exec() a new program.
      • Does not copy the address space of parent into the child.
      • The child calls exec() or exit() right after the vfork().
      • The child runs in the address space of the parent. (exec() ì „ê¹Œì§€ëŠ”)
      • Provides an efficiency.
        • execì´ ë°”ë¡œ í˜¸ì¶œë˜ëŠ” ê²½ìš°ì— íš¨ìœ¨ì ì„
    • vfork() guarantees that the child runs first.


    • Example
    #include "apue.hâ€œ
int glob = 6; /* external variable in initialized data */
int main(void)
{
    int var; /* automatic variable on the stack */
    pid_t pid;
    var = 88;
    
    printf("before vfork\n"); /* we don't flush stdio */
    if ((pid = vfork()) < 0) {
        err_sys("vfork error");
    } else if (pid == 0) { /* child */
        glob++; /* modify parent's variables */
        var++;
        exit(0); /* child terminates */
    }
    /*
 * Parent continues here.
 */
    printf("pid = %d, glob = %d, var = %d\n", getpid(), glob, var);
    exit(0);
}
    • ì‹¤í–‰ (13 í˜ì´ì§€ fork ê²½ìš°ì™€ì˜ ì°¨ì´ì )
    $ ./a.out
before vfork
pid = 29039, glob = 7, var = 89
$

    vforkëŠ” ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ì¦‰ì‹œ ë³µì œí•˜ì§€ ì•Šê³  exec()ì„í•˜ê¸° ì „ê¹Œì§€ëŠ” ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ì˜ ì£¼ì†Œ ê³µê°„ì—ì„œ ì‹¤í–‰ëœë‹¤. ë”°ë¼ì„œ ìì‹ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ ë³€ìˆ˜(var, glob)ì„ ì¦ê°€ ì‹œì¼°ëŠ”ë° ìì‹ê³¼ ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ glob, var ë³€ìˆ˜ì— ëŒ€í•´ ë³„ë„ë¡œ copyë¥¼ ê°€ì§€ê³  ìˆëŠ” ê²ƒì´ ì•„ë‹ˆë¼ ë¶€ëª¨ í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ê°€ ê°–ê³  ìˆëŠ” ê²ƒì„ ê³µìœ í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì´ê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì— ë¶€ëª¨ê°€ ì¦ê°€ì‹œí‚¤ì§€ ì•Šì•˜ë”ë¼ë„ ìì‹ì´ ì¦ê°€ì‹œí‚¨ ê²ƒ ë•Œë¬¸ì— ë¶€ëª¨ê°€ ì¶œë ¥í•˜ëŠ” ë‚´ìš©ì— ì´ê²ƒì´ ë°˜ì˜ë˜ì–´ ë‚˜íƒ€ë‚˜ê²Œ ëœ ê²ƒì´ë‹¤.

    ê³ ë¡œ ì´ ì ì´ fork() ì™€ì˜ ì°¨ì´ì ì´ë¼ê³  í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆë‹¤.
